docs.lead_paragraph: Prevaricate. Equivocate. Fib. Call it what you like, it's still lying. And lying, as everyone knows, is just bad and wrong. Liars have even been promised cruel and eternal punishment. Dante, in his ''Inferno,'' hurled them into the eighth circle of hell, along with other falsifiers, putting them one moral step below violent offenders. Their sin? Deliberate and calculated deception, a transgression apparently worse than the spontaneous crimes of passion.

headline.main: Truth About Lies: They Tell a Lot About a Liar

docs.abstract: University of Pennsylvania researcher Dr Daniel Langleben uses MRI technology to determine brain activity while lying; finds increased activity in certain areas of brain suggest it takes more effort to suppress truth and lie; individuals suffering with antisocial disorder and their unique ability to lie discussed; other psychological reasons why people lie described; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: Prevaricate. Equivocate. Fib. Call it what you like, it's still lying. And lying, as everyone knows, is just bad and wrong.    Liars have even been promised cruel and eternal punishment. Dante, in his ''Inferno,'' hurled them into the eighth circle...

docs.lead_paragraph: Acne has long been known to cause stress. Now, a new study offers evidence that what has long been suspected -- that stress causes acne -- may also be true. Researchers at Stanford put the question to the test by examining students with acne problems on two occasions: once during a relatively stress-free time and again during an exam period. They also administered standardized questionnaires intended to assess stress levels.

headline.main: Acne: A Visible Outbreak of Stress

docs.abstract: Stanford University researcher Dr Alexa B Kimball, reporting in Archives of Dermatology, finds connection between emotional stress and acne breakouts; suggests dermatologists could use information in planning treatment programs; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Acne has long been known to cause stress. Now, a new study offers evidence that what has long been suspected -- that stress causes acne -- may also be true.    Researchers at Stanford put the question to the test by examining students with acne...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Seizures and Epilepsy in Childhood'' (third edition), by Dr. John M. Freeman, Dr. Eileen P. G. Vining and Diana J. Pillas. Johns Hopkins University Press, $19.95. ''Epilepsy: A New Approach,'' by Adrienne Richard and Dr. Joel Reiter. Walker and Company, $15.95. Epilepsy, a neurological disorder set off by a disruption of the brain's electrical activity, has been known for centuries. The disorder is mired in myth, misconception and superstition, and its sufferers have even been linked to witches and devils.
docs.abstract: Authors Dr John M Freeman, Dr Eileen P G Vining and Diana J Pillas dispel mistaken ideas about epilepsy in book Seizures and Epilepsy in Childhood; associated with Pediatric Epilepsy Center at Johns Hopkins, they hope to reassure individuals that in 70 to 80 percent of childhood epilepsy cases patients control or outgrow disorder; Adrienne Richard and Dr Joel Reiter author book Epilepsy: New Approach, in which they give neurological definition of seizures, diagnosis of condition and various treatments; alternative therapies to aid in seizure control described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ''Seizures and Epilepsy in Childhood'' (third edition), by Dr. John M. Freeman, Dr. Eileen P. G. Vining and Diana J. Pillas. Johns Hopkins University Press, $19.95.    ''Epilepsy: A New Approach,'' by Adrienne Richard and Dr. Joel Reiter. Walker and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Abnormal levels of cholesterol, already implicated in cardiovascular disease, also appear to play a role in kidney failure, which is increasing in the United States, a new study reports. Having too much L.D.L., often called the bad cholesterol, or too little H.D.L., the good type, may double the risk of kidney failure, the researchers say in an article in The Journal of the American Society of Nephrology. The cholesterol appears to work on the kidneys much as it does on the cardiovascular system, they said.
docs.abstract: Study, drawn from long-running Physician's Health Study and published in Journal of American Society of Nephrology, shows high levels of bad cholesterol and low levels of good cholesterol contribute to risk of kidney failure not just cardiovascular disease; study director Dr Tobias Kurth of Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston also asserts that medication to reduce cholesterol can benefit both heart and kidneys (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Public health experts from around the country gathered at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta last week to talk about how they could keep 13-year-old Jerel Bullard from having sex. They weren't talking specifically about Jerel, of course. They were talking about the future face of the AIDS epidemic in America. The number of newly reported H.I.V. infections in youth in the United States rose slightly in 2002, according to figures released at the National H.I.V. Prevention Conference. The increases were small but troubling and may be attributed in part to the fact that many of the newly infected young people were too young to have experienced the fear that surrounded H.I.V. before the discovery of effective drugs in the mid-1990's.

headline.main: Making New Efforts to Convince Youths They're Not Invulnerable to H.I.V.

docs.abstract: Public health experts, meeting at Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, discuss possible approaches to disturbing statistic showing increase in new AIDS infections in young adults in 2002; more than half of 40,000 new infections involve people under age 25; Dr Michael Carrera, Children's Aid Society after-school program founder, believes key to preventing AIDS is in empowering young people to make right decisions for themselves by providing individual support and encouraging their creative talents; reports none of 5,000 teenagers enrolled in program over last 19 years have tested positive for HIV; prevention messages are discussed and evaluated for their relevancy for high-risk teens; inherent differences in adolescent patients as opposed to adults are given; possible solutions outlined; photo (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: You have no doubt heard of similar situations in the past. A substance known to be hazardous above a certain level is deemed safe below that, only to discover years later that the so-called safe level was not safe at all. Such has repeatedly been the case with children's exposure to lead, a substance known since 1923 to damage the brain.

headline.main: Even Low Lead Levels Pose Perils for Children

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses new information on lead hazards for children that set much lower thresholds for possible brain damage; Cornell University developmental psychologist Dr Richard L Canfield led study, which will be published in New England Journal of Medicine; Study finds that blood levels under 10 micrograms create greater damage than higher levels of lead; cites need for Centers for Disease Control and World Health Organization to reassess their policies; link between lead exposure and tendency toward criminal and antisocial behavior is indicated by research conducted by developmental psychologist Dr Kim Dietrich at University of Cincinnati; lead testing is suggested, especially when renovation work is being done in and around children's environment; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: You have no doubt heard of similar situations in the past. A substance known to be hazardous above a certain level is deemed safe below that, only to discover years later that the so-called safe level was not safe at all.    Such has repeatedly been...

docs.lead_paragraph: Government warnings urging pregnant women to reduce their consumption of fish that may carry high mercury levels appear to work, researchers say. Writing in the current issue of Obstetrics & Gynecology, the researchers said a survey of 2,235 pregnant women had found that many reported eating less fish.
docs.abstract: Harvard Medical School's Dr Emily Oken is lead author of report appearing in journal Obstetrics & Gynecology that shows women heeded government warnings about mercury levels and reduced fish consumption while pregnant; study, however, warns against overzealous interpretation that eating fish is bad; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Government warnings urging pregnant women to reduce their consumption of fish that may carry high mercury levels appear to work, researchers say.    Writing in the current issue of Obstetrics & Gynecology, the researchers said a survey of 2,235...

docs.lead_paragraph: The next time you're stuck in a crowded subway car or in a long supermarket line, try looking carefully at the faces around you to figure out exactly what expression a face reveals, and what makes you think so. Is it the eyebrows? The lips? The slightly flared nostrils? Deciphering facial expressions, especially of someone you don't know well, is tougher than it appears, as I discovered when I spent an hour or two trying out two CD's by Dr. Paul Ekman. (They are available online at emotionsrevealed.com and cost $29.95 for one, $49.95 for the set of two.)
docs.abstract: Dr Paul Ekman believes there are seven different facial expressions and he offers basic course in learning to identify them; slight physical changes that differentiate emotions discussed (S)
docs.snippet: The next time you're stuck in a crowded subway car or in a long supermarket line, try looking carefully at the faces around you to figure out exactly what expression a face reveals, and what makes you think so. Is it the eyebrows? The lips? The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Smokers who want to reduce the harm posed to babies by secondhand smoke should avoid half measures and simply ban smoking from their homes, a new study warns. Writing in the current BMJ, a British medical journal, researchers said that babies raised in nonsmoking homes had ''small but significant'' differences in their levels of a nicotine byproduct, cotinine, from those raised in homes where smoking was allowed.
docs.abstract: Researchers, writing in BMJ, British medical journal, finds that smoker's efforts to avoid children's rooms or open windows to cut effects of second-hand smoke in home are not effective; hold that only banning smoking entirely helped children; only 18% of those families studied banned smoking in home; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Smokers who want to reduce the harm posed to babies by secondhand smoke should avoid half measures and simply ban smoking from their homes, a new study warns.    Writing in the current BMJ, a British medical journal, researchers said that babies...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Paul Ekman, the professor of psychology who has become the world's most famous face reader, is much in demand these days. The Dalai Lama and Dr. Ekman, who have met twice, found such synergy in their understanding of human emotions that the Dalai Lama gave Dr. Ekman $50,000 in seed money to learn how to improve emotional balance in schoolteachers and other people in high pressure jobs.

headline.main: The 43 Facial Muscles That Reveal Even the Most Fleeting Emotions

docs.abstract: Dr Paul Ekman outlines his theory of finite facial expressions and their meaning; interview; has taught law enforcement personnel and educators and worked with animators,using his research tool called Facial Action Coding System, which assigns meaning to coordination of 43 facial muscles; system was tested against isolated culture of Papua New Guinea and was found to be universal in understanding emotion; link between physical creation of expression and feelings behind them and individual's ability to lie and ability of others to detect lies discussed; photos (L)
